pros: If you are inspired by a collaborative workplace, then BU is a great place to work and grow your network and skills. The tuition remission benefit is also one of the best parts of working at the university.
cons: No room for growth in many offices/departments, no merit-inspired bonuses or support.

review_title: Seemingly great benefits, with some contingencies
job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Tuition remission, healthcare, 401K match after 2 years employment
cons: Tuition remission is counted as taxable income and they only pay 100% for first 4 hours per semester, 401K match after 2 years does not begin if you are a student employee

review_title: Pros and Cons of position at Questrom
pros: Good pay & benefits, good teaching load for tenure-track junior faculty; most departments try to protect you from excessive service or preps
cons: Considerable turmoil now at the top as Questrom seeks a new strategy; new top team finding their way. Doesn't affect your research stream.

job_title: Rock Wall Instructor in Boston, MA
pros: I had a great time working at the rock wall in the fitness and recreation center. My boss was awesome and super understanding, and I got to practice my own skills all day.
cons: The kids can sometimes be awful (think rich suburban and aware of it).

pros: good projects to work on while pursuing your academics,
cons: finding assistantship can be tedious and you have to work for the work hours alloted hours.

pros:
Good location 
The assistant director of BU Housing Kevin Rielly is a great boss who will try his best to work with you.
cons:
The administration overall at BU is overrun by selfishness and incompetence 
You are not cared for at all as an individual

pros: Located in Boston - arguably the most intellectual city in the country, BU is one of the top research universities in the world.
cons: Proximity to Fenway makes commuting a nightmare on game days.

job_title: PhD Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Interdisciplinary research. Several resources for massive computing, including the SCC service.
cons: The distance between the Charles River and Med campuses dos not allow straight forward interaction between the life sciences and engineering students. Nevertheless, the reliable BU Shuttle service allows commute between both campuses.

pros: Hours are scheduled around academic/extracurricular schedules. Good pay for a teaching assistant job. Professor Attaway does a good job of involving the TAs in creating homeworks, grading, and course instruction.
cons: May be asked to work some weekends.

review_title: BU Law is a great place to work
pros: Wonderful people, decent work, encouraging environment!
cons: Educational communications work isn't the same glamor of an ad agency or something of the like, but I think it's a wonderful place to get started as a student worker in your Marketing or Communications career

pros:
- Free room and board
-Meet some great people
-On calls can be switched pretty easily
cons:
-Upper staff not very open to change
-Residence life office is very segmented and communication is difficult

pros: The employee benefits are fantastic - great retirement options and health insurance, plus lots of vacation time (depends on your pay grade, etc.).
cons: Parking can be challenging and navigating around the students on the streets can be a bit nerve racking at times.

review_title: Great and understanding environment for students with busy schedules
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Boston, MA
pros:
-Coordinators and Advisors were very kind and easy to work with
-Flexible schedule around your classes 
-Good pay for student workers on campus
cons: -Sometimes we were given a lot of busy work as opposed to things in our actual job description

pros:
Top ranking in my major. 
Getting full scholarship admission.
Located in a very good city.
Interested in my advisor's field of research.
cons:
In general it is not amongst the high level universities of US.
It is very easy to find a job after graduation(like elsewhere).

pros:
- The work week is 35 hours, never more
- Slow pace of work can be both a pro and a con
cons:
- Low salary and benefits
- Bureaucracy can be frustrating at times
- Rarely promote internally

job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Conducted market analysis and benchmark study on emerging smart-grid competitors, and developed corresponding strategy for electricity market rules design in Great Boston Area.
cons: Synthesized big data drawn from  financial modeling and supply chain management in electricity market design. Developed numerical methods to illustrate project  ndings.

review_title: Excellent experience as a Graduate Teaching Assistant
job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: The professors I've worked with have been great. Knowledgable, of course, interested in helping me become a better teacher, and very accommodating when it comes to my own work.
cons: The commute can be tricky if you live across the river.

job_title: Director of Information Technology in Boston, MA
pros: Great culture to share opinions, grow intellectually and professionally.
cons: The campus is beautiful, right in the heart of Boston.  It can be a challenge to commute to though, but not a reflection overall of the University itself.

pros: Good benefits, good vacation, great location. Generally a good culture, collegiate.
cons: All employee evaluations come from the top down. It is not an easy process for employees to evaluate their supervisors. While probably a necessity for a giant university, it is very bureaucratic.

pros: Not a top place for doing a CS phd, but it's also not too bad. I guess the pro is that you'll be able to live in the Boston city, which is a top place to live in the US.
cons: Not as good as MIT

pros: great benefits. Health dental vision. Lots of days off and having the week of at christmas is a great bonus
cons: They don't seem to care too much about their employees.  There is not a lot of support or recognition

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Boston, MA
pros: Job security and work-life balance.
cons: Office consensus of staying in your lane and not pushing the envelope. Employees are comfortable with where they are, hence the average length of employment being 10+ years. Better benefits (retirement, tuition remission, health care, etc.) at other Boston-area schools.

review_title: Good job for gaining experience or transitioning into other scientific jobs
pros: University seems pretty involved with health of its employees (mentally/physically). Good benefits including taking free or discounted classes from the school.
cons: Low compensation. Departments don't often interact with each other (this is typical in a hospital though).

review_title: I have been having a very enjoyable learning experience at Boston University.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: BU provides a very diversified, open, inviting and supportive environment. People here are very energetic and great to work with.
cons: I wish the campus was bigger so there will be more places for students to hang out.

review_title: Great benefits. Good place to work
pros: BU has excellent benefits - lots of vacation time, great health benefits and you can move up easily.
cons: Because this is a university, there can be a lot of red tape to deal with. Decisions cannot usually be made quickly.

pros: Easy staff to get along with. Very flexible hours and particularly considerate of school work peak times (midterms, finals, etc)
cons: The work itself was often repetitive and was rarely stimulating.

pros: The atmosphere was very innovative. Most of the people are hard workers. The equipment is mostly state of the art.
cons: The pay is low. Boston University tries a little too hard to boost their reputation. People could be a little more collaborative.

review_title: Review of PhD Student from Electrical and Computer Engineering Department of Boston University
pros: Excellent location, encouraging culture, and good interpersonal relationship.
cons: Less regarded since Harvard and MIT are just across the river.

pros: Stable environment for long term employment. The management team are more caring and professional than the average workplace. Benefits package is good.
cons: Salaries are kinda low and not keeping up with regional values. Promotions are slow to arrive but extra work is not.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: general facilities are good, easy access to public transport, great location close to downtown and fenway area, flexible hours for grad student
cons: Not attracted by many research funding agencies, lack of diversity in the grad program, not many female supervisors in engineering school.

pros: Working at BU provides a stable environment and does allow for a lot of professional development opportunities.
cons: Pay for administrators is low, and unless you know someone, it is difficult to advance.

pros: The city of course has a wealth of resources; the university has a new gym; atmosphere collegial; decent benefits; low pressure; staff-friendly
cons: Immediate environment of Kenmore Square/ Commonwealth Avenue unattractive, noisy and hectic; administrative accounting system- SAP/BU Works- terrible; cost of living high.

pros: The people, tuition remission, excellent benefits and time off are all fantastic at Boston University. I really enjoy working there.
cons: Salaries are a bit lower than other academic institutions. Parking costs on the Medical School campus are a little high.

review_title: In the heart of a very bustling city is a University that stands out.
pros: There is an opportunity for growth within the University.
cons: The only con about Boston University that is a very long campus; a hour walk from Kenmore to Commonwealth Ave/North Beacon Street.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: The workload is not that much if you are a graduate student at the same time
cons: The pay is low relative to the other universities specially considering the fact that we are living in an expensive city like Boston

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Love teaching. flexible hours of work
cons:
Salary could be improved according to the living standard of a city such as Boston
More benefits could be added. Dental insurance is not there. These insurances are necessity these days.

pros: The atmosphere is very supportive and the workload is usually very reasonable. Benefit are pretty good too.
cons: Cross-departmental communication isn't particularly smooth, some jobs are comparatively underpaid, and the university-wide networks are not user-friendly.

job_title: Leadership Gift Officer in Boston, MA
pros: Love working for a university and company that treats me well as a person, LGBTQ community member, and part-time student
cons: Benefits are generally very good, but could use vision insurance or small copay for insurance.

review_title: It is a great environment to work with. People are nice, friendly and talented.
job_title: Student Services Professional in Boston, MA
pros: The managers at the Student Dinning Service is nice. They are flexible when you cannot make it on time. Coworkers are friendly to corporate with.
cons: Do not pay well

review_title: Perfect way to achieve an advanced degree
pros:
Great Benefits, i.e. Vacation, Medical and Dental, Tuition Remission
Lots of support for education advancement
cons:
Low salaries
Too much bureaucracy
No real empowerment for employees to make decisions

pros:
-Rarely asked to do something besides answering phones/maintenance requests
-Friendly staff, approachable superiors
cons: -Forced to work during finals week

review_title: Great place to start in Educational media
pros: You get to learn all the new trends in Educational media and get to meet a lot of freelancers working there.
cons: For what you do, the pay is not that great.

pros: The collaborative working environment always inspire people to come up with brilliant ideas. All the professors and faculty are team-oriented and always open to  opinions
cons: The class design could have used more outside resources such as alumni

review_title: Great enterprise, great work, ok location
pros:
Time off during the holidays
Tuition assistance for BU classes
cons: I work in the medical school and due to the area the campus is located and population of some sketchy characters, walking about late can feel very stressful.

pros: Tuition reimbursement, TIAA/CREF, on public transportation
cons: Internal politics unethically influence hiring and promotion.

review_title: Great place if you're looking to pay for your education through BU
pros: Tuition remission for full-time employees, 2 weeks vacation plus many university holidays off
cons: Low salary considering responsibilities of the job but they can get away with it because they offer tuition remission

pros: Great experience working with students and good refresher of old material for those applying to graduate school
cons: Sometimes the other staff can be somewhat rude.

pros: Great people and a very positive atmosphere in the office
cons: Graduate assistantships in the School of Visual Arts hardly pay anything. Kind of a joke, actually, but at least working in the SVA office was a good experience.

pros:
Great work-life balance - I never have to take work home.
Flexible work schedule including work from home days.
The benefits are pretty good.
cons:
To make changes takes ages due to the bureaucracy.
The raises are around 1-2.5% every year.
There are no real career paths.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: I had some good experiences with my professor.  Helping him with the reliability of new course and helping out students with their doubts made me understand the concepts even better.
cons: We have to dedicate few hours for TA job

review_title: Great place to work and learn
pros: friendly environment, a great place to learn and grow. facilities are good. location is very convenient. safe neighborhood.
cons: I don't see any cons for Boston University so far. All are very pleasant and nice.

pros: The coworkers were the only redeeming factor
cons:
-training was long and unnecessary
-management was poor and unorganized
- they are delusional of what they think students want, they try and run the school like a summer camp. these students are adults and not children

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Many things to learn and outstanding professors to work with. Rich resources for research and many seminars to attend.
cons: The work needs patient and passion. Sometimes the results of the research are depressing, need strong heart to move on.

pros: Get to work with some of the coolest marine animals, awesome boss (Justin Scace), flexible hours, great people.
cons: None! Slightly messy lab but they're working on cleaning it up :)

job_title: Assistant Dean for Finance and Technology in Boston, MA
pros: flexible work times, time off and great benefits
cons: working with a bureaucracy that rivals a government job

pros: Tuition remission, good benefits, I'm part of the union so my hours are very standard. I also love the location.
cons: Nothing really.  Depending on your department you probably won't advance very far without some kind of advanced degree.

pros:
Good HR, orientation, benefits packages
Took advantage of the ability to take courses as a benefit, which furthered my career after leaving this job.
cons: It's academia, there isn't much room for vertical movement without seeking a higher degree yourself.

review_title: Great on-campus job, tons of flexibility.
pros: Great for organizational minded people, easy to do and there are opportunities to multitask and complete your personal work.
cons: The mailroom can get pretty busy and chaotic during peak hours.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Good location, networking, and opportunities for collaboration
cons: Department-dependent experience, generally poor leadership and direction. Little to no support for graduate students needs, clearly a money-making operation to extract talent out of students.

pros: Teh benefits are great, especially vactiona time and tuition remission. Depending on your job there can be flexibility in schedule
cons: low pay, lots of red tape

pros: It's a good place to gain experience teaching in a large private university setting.
cons: Other schools pay better, administrative procedures need improvement - lots of headaches.

pros:
A culture of respecting and investing in each other
Great work environment with individual offices, new facilities.
Profitable every quarter with a generous profit sharing plan
cons: is a loner who likes to work independently. It's all about collaboration.

pros: BU was well equipped with a soundproof booth and a script on an iPad.
cons: I prefer to stand while voice acting but they it was set up so I had to remain seated. Not a big problem though.

pros: very flexible and understanding of my class schedule and availability
cons: just too quiet of an environment for my personal taste

pros: I have been in BU for three years. Very well equipped labs.  The professors are very helpful and they are open to discussions. very well funded researches.
cons: The University is expensive, for example parking is very expensive.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros:
opportunity to get hands-on experience on research stuff
more conversation with the professor in professional fields
flexibility in schedule
a source of income for grad student
cons: the job is good and don't have much to mention for Cons

pros: Nice environment, people are respectful, but not super friendly as is customary in the city of Boston
cons: bad neighbourhoods surround the Medical Campus, must be careful of you immediate surrroundings

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Nice. There are all sort of awesome research going on. You just need to find where you belong.
cons: Everyone seems to be disconnected. One lab does this, another does this. Nobody really knows who's doing what.

pros: Big university, tons of events and groups to be involved with. Makes networking easy.
cons: Due to the size, there is a lot of bureaucracy. It can be hard to to organize events or get some things done.

pros: The location is nice and easily accessible for commuters. Can work according to your own plan, a.k.a, very flexible.  Professors and colleagues are very kindly and helpful.
cons: May have harsh winter conditions from year to year.

pros: Caring & supportive environment, with free food and drinks on a semi-regular basis. The other members of staff have become like family to me.
cons: NONE at all that I can think of.

pros: Salaries a bit lower, but perks a bit higher than average.
cons: Have to have patience to get through the paperwork when applying.

pros: Relatively easy job duties, and great benefits including tuition remission (huge!), paid holiday intercession, good vacation and sick time, holidays parties, etc
cons: Very low pay, esp in comparison to other private higher education institutions around Boston

pros: Well-funded university to conduct research, good benefits, and good support for research.
cons: Expensive to park and, like any university, a lot of red-tape to get anything accomplished.

pros: I worked at BU as a work-study student. It was fine overall. Pretty easy to find a job also.
cons: Obviously not great pay.

pros: Lots of institutional support, generally friendly fellow students/staff/professors
cons: Biochemistry lab coordinator means well but is horrible to work with. Slow to get institutional support in general.

review_title: Entry level position: Opportunities for Growth Outside Department
job_title: Senior Enrollment Service Advisor in Boston, MA
pros: Union representation: This is dependent on salary grade. Opportunities for growth outside of department.
cons: High turnover in Combined Enrollment Services for employees and management. Limited opportunities for growth within the department.

pros: Great benefits, supportive  colleagues, higher ed setting in Boston is busy and invigorating
cons: Campus very spread out and traffic is congested, crossing Comm Avenue can be sometimes dangerous due to trolleys and irregular and uneven walking areas

pros: Great benefits and a wonderful community to work amongst. Great opportunities for advancement.
cons: Sometimes things move slowly, however, that is an issue with higher ed and less so with the university as a whole.

pros: Slow work enviroment yet laid back enviroment. Compensates competitively with very generous benefits.
cons: Highyl bureaucratic and tiresome at times. However, work enviroments differ by department.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros:
Lots of opportunities to network.
Love the city, lots to do.
Research is interesting.
cons:
Dismal pay as a graduate student.
Not a lot of career development guidance for after graduation.
Support from administration is lukewarm after first year.

pros: Great opportunities for higher ed, nice benefits (tuition reimbursements kick in right away)
cons: It takes forever to get through the interview process; slow. Getting in is difficult if you don't already have insider connections.

pros: I am working for the AD department of MET. The professor is very nice and allows flexible working time.
cons: The professor would like to change mind all the time, and sometimes makes me hard to follow.

pros: Tuition remission is great but careful; after two classes/year, you're heavily taxed out of paycheck. health plan options are great. convenience of city campus is great!
cons: Low pay compared to other schools in area

review_title: Postdoc at Center for Space Physics, BU
pros: Amazingly friendly environment! Gives you a great sense of belonging to a community. You don't have to sit in your office all day!
cons: Obviously salary is low compared to industry!

job_title: IT Help Desk Support in Boston, MA
pros: Fantastic team that truly cares about each other and functions about team. Not too concerned with job titles and hierarchy, constantly trying to better the system together.
cons: Nothing much to complain about!

job_title: Student Media Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Laid back, managers very understanding.
cons: Sometimes you have to spend an hour or two helping a prof record which is very boring but you can be on your phone during it at least.

review_title: Great University, but very few decent Chemistry PIs that care about mentorship
pros: Great collaborative environment to do research
cons: Lack of diversity in the Chemistry department, graduate students have to fend for themselves during thesis preparation and defense.

review_title: Great Experience being a TA - LOW pay, but nice addition to resume.
pros: Professors and students are bright and great to work with.
cons: Low wages and spent office hours waiting for students to never show up.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: A intense plunge into research with great opportunities for publishing, presenting, and building a career all while at a top university.
cons: Time consuming and rigorous, low salary makes it hard to live in Boston.

review_title: Been there 20 years, so that should tell you something...
job_title: Learning and Event Technology Specialist in Rio de Janeiro
pros: Free tuition for yourself and discounted for family, great benefits, great people, pretty good schedule
cons: They demand a lot for not a lot of money.

job_title: Academic Counselor in Vitória, Espírito Santo
pros: Good salary and benefits, Professional Development opportunities,
cons: Not a lot of room for growth, necessary changes are slow to be implemented, departments across campus are siloed and feel disconnected from each other

pros: Good benefits. Ability to attend classes at very discounted rates. Good for those looking to acquire a graduate degree.
cons: Very stagnant workplace. Limited opportunities to move up.

review_title: A research position where you have great opportunity to learn from the best.
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in São Paulo, São Paulo

- Freedom to Research on your own

review_title: It has been a great place to develop as a scientist
job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in São Paulo, São Paulo

cons: Poor senior management in terms of interaction with staff

pros: Depending on your professor and what class you are working for the hours are usually based on your schedule and not the other way around

pros: A lot of perks like free tickets to events, get to meet celebrities hired for events, and tons of cool experiences

pros: Great benefits, including the opportunity to take classes for very little cost, work/life balance was excellent and encouraged by my supervisors.

pros: Because I have experience in as a custodian, that's why I want to work again for BU

review_title: everything is great except the pay

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Boston, MA

review_title: very good place to start out
pros: very good place to start out tho it may not be the best for some people

cons: Not all students get the same wages as an assistant, I was one of the lucky ones.

pros: It is a really good opportunity to work at Boston Universtiy as a part-time graduate student.

Top-tier research university in Biomedical Engineering
